chunks.text: We'll cover some basic arithmetic operators,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: built-in math functions,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: a few functions from the math module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's begin with some really easy stuff.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're going to cover some basic arithmetic operators.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say we have a variable, friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Currently you have zero friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you need to increment a variable by one, you could say,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: friends, the name of the variable equals the name of the variable again, plus one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So the plus sign is the addition operator.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I think we do have a little bit of experience with that already.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So if I were to print my variable friends,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: guess what? You now have one friend.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We could also shorten this line of code.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You could say friends plus equals one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would do the same thing.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is known as an augmented assignment operator.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now we'll give you the same result.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I prefer to use augmented assignment operators just because they take less text.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I think they're easier to read.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now let's use subtraction.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Friends equals friends minus two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So of course, minus is the subtraction operator.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You have negative two friends, I guess.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you were to use the augmented assignment operator, that would be friends minus equals two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There you still have negative two friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, multiplication.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's change friends to how about five friends equals friends times three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You now have 15 friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then the augmented assignment operator version of this would be friends times equals three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So again, you have 15 friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's cover division.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Friends equals friends divided by two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So we have 2.5 friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Somebody was cut in half.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have half a friend.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe it's just their legs or torso or something.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then the augmented assignment operator would be friends divided by equals two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And the result is still the same.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now exponents.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Friends equals friends to the power of two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So friends is currently five.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Friends to the power of two would be five times five, which is 25.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The augmented assignment operator version of this equation would be friends exponent equals two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And again, friends is 25.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we have modulus.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Modulus gives you the remainder of any division.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Suppose we have 10 friends instead of five.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will assign a new variable remainder.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Remander equals friends.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The percent sign is known as the modulus operator.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It will give us the remainder of any division.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I were to divide my group of friends by three, we will have one remaining.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll store the remainder within a separate variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We would have a remainder of one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's kind of like in class, when the teacher says for everybody in the class to go into groups of three,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then there's always that one kid that's by themselves.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's kind of the same concept.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're dividing our friends into groups of three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then the modulus will give you the remainder.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we divided our group of friends into groups of two, well, 10 divides by two evenly.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So there is no remainder.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So that is the modulus operator.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's fairly popular to use this operator to find if a number is even or odd because it will divide by two evenly if that number is even.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If the remainder is one, that means that the original number is odd.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, so yeah, those are some basic arithmetic operators.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Additions, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponentiation, then modulus.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now what we're going to do is cover some built-in math-related functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Suppose we have three variables.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: X equals 3.14.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Y equals 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Z equals 5.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It doesn't matter if these are floating point numbers or whole integers.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The first is the round function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have a variable named result.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to round X.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So there is a built-in round function after the set of parentheses.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can add some value or variable to be rounded.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So we will round X to the nearest whole integer.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then print the result.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So our result is 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So that's the round function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With the absolute value function, we can find the absolute value of a number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's change Y to be negative 4 instead of 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll take result equals a, b, s, which means absolute value of Y.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The absolute value is the distance away from 0 as a whole number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The absolute value of negative 4 is 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's change Y back to 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There's a built-in power function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Results equals power.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we'll need a base and an exponent.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What's Y to the power of 3?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would be 4 times 4 times 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Which is 64.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's the power function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can raise the base to a given power.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The next two are really useful.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using the max function, we can find the maximum value of various values.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What's the maximum value between X, Y and Z?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I'll just need to store this value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Results equals the max between X, Y and Z.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The maximum value is 5.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Otherwise, there's min.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What's the minimum value between X, Y and Z?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would be 3.14.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In this next section, we do have some very useful constants and functions from the math class.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But we'll need to import the math module at the top of our text editor.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So import math.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you need the value of pi, you'll type the name of the math module, dot pi.
